events.covLStrEventDescription: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.
events.eventDescription: The docker service container is configured to permit writing to the root filesystem. This makes some security attack vectors such as privilege escalation, denial-of-service or authorization bypass possible since the container instance's filesystem can be tampered with.

events.covLStrEventDescription: Explicitly set the `read-only` attribute of the service to `true` to create a service container with a read-only filesystem.
events.eventDescription: Explicitly set the `read-only` attribute of the service to `true` to create a service container with a read-only filesystem.

events.covLStrEventDescription: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.
events.eventDescription: The Docker Compose file sets the `no-new-privileges` attribute to `false` or omits it as the default value is `false`. This doesn't restrict the container from acquiring additional privileges via SUID or SGID bits. This allows privilege escalation, meaning a user can set the security context of the container and can perform root-level operations.

events.covLStrEventDescription: Disable container privilege escalation by explicitly setting `no-new-privileges` to `true`.
events.eventDescription: Disable container privilege escalation by explicitly setting `no-new-privileges` to `true`.

events.covLStrEventDescription: The Docker container requests the `NET_RAW` capability, either explicitly or by default, granting access to the host's network interfaces.
events.eventDescription: The Docker container requests the `NET_RAW` capability, either explicitly or by default, granting access to the host's network interfaces.

events.covLStrEventDescription: Explicitly remove the `NET_RAW` capability by adding either `NET_RAW` or `ALL` to the `cap_drop` list and avoiding the `NET_RAW` capability in the `cap_add` list.
events.eventDescription: Explicitly remove the `NET_RAW` capability by adding either `NET_RAW` or `ALL` to the `cap_drop` list and avoiding the `NET_RAW` capability in the `cap_add` list.

events.covLStrEventDescription: The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.
events.eventDescription: The Docker container is not configured to drop all default capabilities and then add only required one. Thus the container may be granted excessive privileges which violate the least privilege principle.

events.covLStrEventDescription: Remove all the default capabilities from the list of capabilities by setting the `cap_drop` value to `ALL` and then add only specific capabilities needed by a container.

events.covLStrEventDescription: The Docker Compose file does not explicitly set `image` attribute with a specific stable version. Pinning the version of the base image will make the container being built more predictable. Relying on the latest version may silently inherit newer packages, which in the best case may affect application reliability and in the worst case may introduce vulnerabilities.

events.covLStrEventDescription: Explicitly set the `image` attribute to a specific stable version.
